facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 176 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 11, 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 80 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 11, 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax, Re- ference No. 80 of 1959. T. Desai and J.P. Goyal, for the appellant.

facts.text: M/s. Ram Kumar Agarwalla Brothers were carrying on business at Calcutta as share-brokers, share dealers and paper merchants.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah J. M s. Ram Kumar Agarwalla Brothers--hereinafter called the assessees-were carrying on business at Calcutta as share-brokers, share dealers and paper merchants, Swadeshi Cotton Mills

facts.text: Swadeshi Cotton Mills Co. Ltd. operates at Kanpur a large unit producing cotton textiles.

facts.text: Swadeshi Cotton Mills was originally managed by M/s. Horseman Brothers.

anchor.surface_text: styled M s. Horseman Brothers. Some time early in 1946 M s. Horseman Brothers desired to dispose of their share-holding in the Company, and to part with the Managing Agency. facts.text: M/s. Mangturam Jaipuria addressed a letter on April 29, 1946 to David Mitchell.

anchor.surface_text: M s. Mangturam Jaipuria addressed a letter on April 29, 1946 to David, Mitchell to the following effect With reference to your negotiations to acquire the companytrolling interest in the Swadeshi Cotton Mills Co. Ltd., we companyfirm that we and our associates are desirous of purchasing the same and in the event of your securing the same for us and upon your giving up all claims to purchase the same and assigning to us and our associates any interest that you may have acquired therein, we hereby agree to pay you and your companyleagues a capital sum of Rs. 6,00,000/-.

facts.text: Letter from M/s. Mangturam Jaipuria stated they agree to pay Rs. 6,00,000 upon securing the controlling interest for them and giving up claims.

anchor.surface_text: to the following effect With reference to your negotiations to acquire the companytrolling interest in the Swadeshi Cotton Mills Co. Such, payment to be made upon companypletion of the purchase by us.

facts.text: M/s. Mangturam Jaipuria obtained a letter of guarantee for Rs. 6,00,000/- from the Imperial Bank of India in favour of David Mitchell.

anchor.surface_text: M s. Mangturam Jaipuria also obtained a letter of guarantee for Rs. 6,00,000/- from the Imperial Bank of India in favour of David Mitchell. M s. Mangturam Jaipuria purchased the shareholding of M s. Horseman Brothers for Rs. 4,03,00,000/-. Thereafter the amount of Rs. 6,00,000/- was duly paid to David Mitchell, Rowan Hodge and the assessees, and it was divided equally between them-each receiving Rs. 2 lakhs.

On the plea of the assessees that the amount of Rs. 2,00,000 was received by them as companysideration for agreeing to refrain from carrying on their business and was on that account number taxable as their income, and that in any event it was a number-recurring casual receipt, there was difference of opinion between the two Members who companystituted the Appellate Tribunal, and the appeal was referred to a third Member who remanded the case for a finding on certain matters on which the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was silent.

facts.text: High Court of Calcutta held there was ample material to support Tribunal's finding that receipt was revenue receipt from venture in nature of trade.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Calcutta held that there was ample material to support the finding of the Tribunal that the receipt in question, was a revenue receipt from a venture in the nature of trade. With special leave, the assessees have appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, holding receipt was revenue receipt earned in course of business of assessees.

anchor.surface_text: The receipt must therefore be regarded as a revenue receipt earned in the companyrse of the business of the assessees. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 11, 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax, Re- ference No. 80 of 1959. T. Desai and J.P. Goyal, for the appellant.

The High Court of Calcutta held that there was ample material to support the finding of the Tribunal that the receipt in question, was a revenue receipt from a venture in the nature of trade. With special leave, the assessees have appealed to this Court.

holdings.text: The terms of the letter addressed by M s. Mangturam Jaipuria to David Mitchell make it abundantly clear that Rs. 6 lakhs were agreed to be paid primarily as remuneration for services to be rendered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of the letter confirms payment was for securing the interest, i.e., services rendered.

holdings.text: The Tribunal had also called for a report from the Appellate Assistant Commissioner... The Tribunal accepted the report of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, and observed that the assessees had no intention to buy the controlling interest in the Company.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal had also called for a report from the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and that Officer, as we have already observed, expressly recorded that the payment made to the assessees and their associaties was for services rendered in acquiring the controlling interest for M s. Mangturam Jaipuria and number for dissuading them in competing for the purchase of the shares. The Tribunal accepted the report of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal correctly accepted AAC's report that payment was for services in acquiring interest, not for non-competition.

holdings.text: The conclusion recorded by the Tribunal that the assessees David Mitchell and Rowan Hodge had no intention to acquire the controlling interest, but were seeking to associate themselves in a venture in the nature of trade, cannot in the circumstances be said to be without evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion recorded by the Tribunal that the assessees David Mitchell and Rowan Hodge had nointention to acquire the companytrolling interest, but were seeking to associate themselves in a venture in the nature of trade, cannot in the circumstances be said to be without evidence. The conclusion that the assessees and their two associates received Rs. 6,00,000/- number in consideration of refraining from competing in the purchase of, the controlling interest, but as remuneration for services rendered is based on evidence before the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence including lack of financing plans and associates' roles supports finding of no genuine purchase intention.

holdings.text: The conclusion that the assessees and their two associates received Rs. 6,00,000/- not in consideration of refraining from competing in the purchase of, the controlling interest, but as remuneration for services rendered is based on evidence before the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion that the assessees and their two associates received Rs. 6,00,000/- number in companysideration of refraining from companypeting in the purchase of, the companytrolling interest, but as remuneration for services rendered is based on evidence before the Tribunal. The receipt must therefore be regarded as a revenue receipt earned in the course of the business of the assessees.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence from letter, AAC report, and circumstances shows remuneration for services, not capital or non-compete payment.

holdings.text: The receipt must therefore be regarded as a revenue receipt earned in the course of the business of the assessees.

anchor.surface_text: The receipt must therefore be regarded as a revenue receipt earned in the companyrse of the business of the assessees. holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on findings of services in course of share broking business and venture in trade.

holdings.text: Under S. 4(3)(vii) receipts which are of a casual and non-recurring nature are not liable to be included in the computation of the total income of the assessee but the rule in express terms does not apply to capital gains, receipts arising from business or the exercise of a profession or vocation and receipts by way of addition to the remuneration of an employee.

C. 136.  2  9 I.T.R. 642. number apply to capital gains, receipts arising from business or the exercise of a profession or vocation and receipts by way of addition to the remuneration of an employee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory exception excludes business receipts from casual non-recurring exemption; applies here.

holdings.text: These cases have, on the findings recorded by the Tribunal no relevance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents distinguished as they involved payments for refraining from business, unlike services here.

anchor.surface_text: Higgs v. Oliver    and in Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay v. The Mills Store Co. Karachi 2 . In Higgss case   a professional actor who had agreed to give his exclusive services to a film companypany in companysideration of a fixed sum,. and a proportion of the net profits from exploitation of a film was, after the agreement was fulfilled, given a sum of 15,000 a companysideration for an undertaking number to act, produce or direct any film for any person for a period of eighteen months.

precedents.cited_proposition: payment for refraining from carrying on business is not taxable as revenue receipt
precedents.cited_holding: the amount paid was not for carrying on business, but for refraining from carrying on the business, and was not taxable

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay v. The Mills Store Co. Karachi

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay v. The Mills Store Co. Karachi 2 . In Higgss case   a professional actor who had agreed to give his exclusive services to a film companypany in companysideration of a fixed sum,. and a proportion of the net profits from exploitation of a film was, after the agreement was fulfilled, given a sum of 15,000 a companysideration for an undertaking number to act, produce or direct any film for any person for a period of eighteen months. It was held that the amount paid was number for carrying on business, but for refraining from carrying on the business, and was number taxble. In the Mills Store Companys case 2  under an agreement for a stated companysideration the assessee Company parted with the oil tanks and installations and other structures and goodwill and leasehold rights held by it in respect of the land on which its business of storing petroleum and petroleum products was carried,

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion recorded by the Tribunal that the assessees David Mitchell and Rowan Hodge had nointention to acquire the companytrolling interest, but were seeking to associate themselves in a venture in the nature of trade, cannot in the circumstances be said to be without evidence. The conclusion that the assessees and their two associates received Rs. 6,00,000/- number in consideration of refraining from competing in the purchase of, the controlling interest, but as remuneration for services rendered is based on evidence before the Tribunal.
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with companyts.
